ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about how to write college-level essays. I think I was stuck in the structure I learned from high school, but Professor Homans worked with me a lot to expand my capabilities as a writer.
I greatly improved as an English writer and became a better critical reader. Exposure to important American literature texts.
Read a good variety of American literature, learned how to grapple with the nations contentious history through the lens of literature. Also really improved my writing!

I gained a lot of confidence in my close reading skills, and I got a much better sense of what a good close reading paper can look like. I was also exposed to a wide range of American literature, and my idea of what constitutes "American literature" in general was greatly expanded.

paper writing
close reading
research
I learned about the problems and history of America through it's literature and authors/documentarists.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Homans is seriously the best. She clearly cares so much about her students and each work we read was just perfect for my understanding of the class. I came out of this semester with a new perspective on what makes up American Literature and a greater appreciation for writing.

Strengths: peer review and breakout rooms
Weaknesses: Sometimes discussions were a bit slow (probably a consequence of the virtual format), there could have been more writing guidance in the beginning, and some feedback was a bit harsh. Though helpful, some of the feedback did not account for the fact that people have different educational backgrounds and this semester was challenging for everyone.
Strengths: reading list, which varies by prof; course open to non-majors so somewhat accessible

In general, I really liked the way this course was set up. I think the main way it could be improved is if class discussions were more guided by the students' interest, rather than the professor bringing specific topics that she wanted us to discuss. We read very rich texts this semester, and I felt like we didn't get to fully explore some of them.

Strengths: interesting readings, good spacing of papers, 

Weaknesses: unreasonable reading load, not enough discussion time on each reading

I think the content is amazing, however, it was often too much to read and focus on in class. I think we could have delved much deeper into specific pieces rather than having a brief understanding of a large array of pieces.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It was not too bad, discussions were fun and invigorating and I enjoyed the times when we had breakout groups. I really appreciated Professor Homans willingness to meet over zoom to discuss our papers.
Breakout rooms were excellent.
The virtual seminar format was a good alternative to an in-person seminar
For some classes, we were put into breakout rooms to discuss specific passages, and I felt that this was a great way to get to know my classmates better and engage with the course material more.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely, but you must take it with Professor Homans. She brings such an incredible perspective and life to the class, and its so clear that she loves what she does and cares about her students personal success. The books we read were surprisingly representational of American Literature and I got to explore a lot of pieces that I hadnt heard of before.
No, there are better English courses at Yale.
Yes! A great opportunity to not only read American lit, but also to consider the significance of America and how this is conveyed by the voices in the texts you read

I would recommend it if you are a quick reader and very interested in American literature and its politics/history. If you need to fulfill the English major requirement, it's a relatively interesting and straightforward class to take. I would warn that the reading load is heavy, and you will likely not be able to finish all of the reading every night.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: NA
seminar over zoom
